Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Chemical and Microbiological Quality of Floodwaters in Houston Following Hurricane Harvey

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Hurricane Harvey landed in Texas as a Saffir-Simpson Category 4 hurricane at 10 p.m. CST on August 25, 2017. Harvey stalled over Texas for several days and brought an unprecedented amount of rainfall into Houston that exceeded 50 inches over some parts of the Greater Metro area. Such unprecedented flooding in an urban area with abundant industrial activity has the potential to produce widespread contamination of waterways, soils and sediment by chemical pollutants and microbiological pathogens. A major issue with understanding the potential impact of such events is that they occur relatively infrequently and are of too short duration to allow for data collection and scientific evaluation using the traditional proposal evaluation and funding processes. This proposal seeks to remedy that problem by rapidly characterizing the chemical pollution and microbiological contamination in Houston waterways post-Harvey to provide both an understanding of the extent of pollution, as well as to provide a base of comparison for subsequent studies of the recovery of the environment over time to support future decision making.

The specific project objectives are to: (i) understand the spatial distribution of various contaminants in Houston water systems post-Harvey; (ii) collect a one-of-its-kind dataset to understand the recovery of the system after such a catastrophic event; and (iii) use state-of-the-art metagenomics techniques to define the microbiological condition of Houston waterways post-disaster and relationship to community health. Four waterways will be studied: Brays, Buffalo, and Greens and Peach Creek represent different flow and land use/land cover regimes, and pollutant sources. Sample collection will encompass the water column, and soil and sediment samples from inundated areas and in-stream locations. Chemical analyses of metals, organic pollutants, and both state-of-the-art and more conventional microbiological assessment techniques will enable detailed investigation of the health hazards to surrounding communities in the wake of Harvey. These data will support decision-making, building capacity and increasing resilience within metropolitan urban water infrastructure in the face of extreme weather events.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF funded RAPID project was aimed at understanding the recovery process in natural water systems after a hurricane or a severe storm event. The scope encompassed collection of longitudinal water and sediment quality data after Hurricane Harvey for a number of constituents including organics, metals, and indicator bacteria. The scope also involved detailed microbiologic metagenomics analyses to determine potential associations between changes in microbial communities and the presence of pollutants in the water body. Sampling teams mobilized right after Harvey and collected weekly samples for near 6 months in a number of watersheds in the Greater Houston metropolitan area that reflected different levels of development and industrial/commercial activities. The team analyzed the extensive dataset collected after Harvey and developed regression models and correlations among the water and sediment quality indicators. Subsequent to the sampling phase, the project received a supplement to support a doctoral student as an INTERN with the City of Houston Mayor's Recovery Office. The doctoral student spent six months in Houston?s Recovery Office and engaged with the staff to learn and understand the policy and decision making process that local governments undertake to develop recovery and mitigation strategies. The doctoral student had the opportunity to learn first hand what the specific issues and damages that Harvey brought forth and to understand the balance between community input, using local resources for recovery and receiving support from the federal government towards resiliency. As a doctoral student, this was a very important growth experience in terms of connecting the science to policy and decision-making that she would not have had otherwise. The experience included interactions with other national and international experts on resiliency and lessons learned in other countries.

Several important outcomes from the project were realized:

  • Two dissertations and several papers were published based on the Harvey data collected during the field sampling phase of the project. A number of papers are in progress as of this writing including papers with undergraduate students and high school research participants,
  • One of the undergraduate students involved in the research was inspired to continue on to graduate school and has applied and was accepted as a doctoral student,
  • Another undergraduate student involved in the research applied and was awarded a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) fellowship for summer 2020 and a University of Houston Provost Undergraduate Research Scholarship (PURS) for Spring 2020,
  • The longitudinal data collected after Harvey indicated that natural water systems that have little to no anthropogenic activities recovered within 1-2 weeks after a flood or hurricane,
  • Depending on the type of anthropogenic activities, recovery of the natural water system could take up to 6 months after a severe event,
  • The widespread nature of flooding during Harvey led to inundation for extended periods of time and for water to reside longer in flood control reservoirs. This led to significantly poorer water quality within the reservoirs that once released, the flood water adversely impacted receiving streams in manner not observed previously. For example, the pH after floodwater release in the receiving stream approached 5,
  • Detailed microbial analyses can serve as a sentry of releases of pollutants from industrial activities during a severe event due to observable changes in their diversity,
  • Metal concentrations did not exhibit levels beyond historical levels in the sampled streams, however, this was attributed to the significant amount of runoff that served to dilute metal concentrations,
  • Locations within the natural water systems that were downstream of industrialized activities reflected elevated concentrations in pollutants specific to the industries,
  • Overall, indicator bacteria, while elevated post-Harvey, were still within the relatively high-concentration ranges observed from conventional in-stream monitoring data,
  • INTERN experiences with local government as experienced by the doctoral student are invaluable. Her engagement and learning activities provided her with transformational ideas for her dissertation including how to incorporate a societal and environmental context for flood mitigation using green infrastructure,
  • INTERN experiences also led to the development of a publication on cross-watershed transfer of flood waters during Harvey that is in progress as of this writing,
  • INTERN experiences have incentivized the PhD scholar to expand their horizon beyond engineering and consider the social sciences as an interdisciplinary domain that has significant relevance to resilience to natural hazards and engaging stakeholders and communities in mitigation.
